description: Master the four major financial statements: Balance Sheet, Income Statement, Cash Flow Statement, and Statement of Changes in Equity

slides.title: Welcome to Financial Statements
slides.content:
# Introduction to Financial Statements

Financial statements are the **primary means** of communicating a company's financial performance and position to stakeholders.

## What You Will Learn

- **Balance Sheet** - Snapshot of financial position
- **Income Statement** - Performance over a period
- **Cash Flow Statement** - How cash moves through the business
- **Statement of Changes in Equity** - Changes in owner's interest

## Why Financial Statements Matter

| Stakeholder | Uses Statements To |
|-------------|-------------------|
| Investors | Decide whether to buy/sell stock |
| Creditors | Assess ability to repay loans |
| Management | Make strategic decisions |
| Employees | Evaluate job security |
| Government | Calculate taxes owed |

## The Financial Statement Relationship

```
Income Statement
      |
      v (Net Income)
Statement of Changes in Equity
      |
      v (Ending Equity)
Balance Sheet
      |
      v (Cash balance ties to)
Cash Flow Statement
```

> **Key Insight:** All four statements are interconnected and must be read together for a complete picture!

slides.title: The Balance Sheet Overview
slides.content:
# The Balance Sheet

## Also Known As: Statement of Financial Position

The balance sheet shows a company's **financial position at a specific point in time** - like a financial photograph.

## The Fundamental Formula

**Assets = Liabilities + Shareholders Equity**

## Structure of the Balance Sheet

### Assets (What We Own)

**Current Assets** (converted to cash within 1 year)
- Cash and Cash Equivalents
- Accounts Receivable
- Inventory
- Prepaid Expenses

**Non-Current Assets** (held for more than 1 year)
- Property, Plant, and Equipment
- Intangible Assets
- Long-term Investments

### Liabilities (What We Owe)

**Current Liabilities** (due within 1 year)
- Accounts Payable
- Short-term Debt
- Accrued Expenses

**Non-Current Liabilities** (due after 1 year)
- Long-term Debt
- Bonds Payable
- Deferred Tax Liabilities

### Shareholders Equity (Owner's Interest)
- Common Stock
- Retained Earnings
- Additional Paid-in Capital

> **Remember:** The balance sheet must ALWAYS balance!

slides.title: Balance Sheet Example
slides.content:
# Balance Sheet in Action

## Sample Balance Sheet

**ABC Company Balance Sheet**
*As of December 31, 2024*

### ASSETS
```
Current Assets:
  Cash                      $50,000
  Accounts Receivable        30,000
  Inventory                  45,000
  Prepaid Insurance           5,000
  ---------------------------------
  Total Current Assets      $130,000

Non-Current Assets:
  Property & Equipment      $200,000
  Less: Accumulated Deprec.  (40,000)
  Intangible Assets           25,000
  ---------------------------------
  Total Non-Current Assets  $185,000
  ---------------------------------
  TOTAL ASSETS              $315,000
```

### LIABILITIES & EQUITY
```
Current Liabilities:
  Accounts Payable          $25,000
  Salaries Payable           10,000
  Short-term Debt            15,000
  ---------------------------------
  Total Current Liabilities  $50,000

Non-Current Liabilities:
  Long-term Debt            $80,000
  ---------------------------------
  TOTAL LIABILITIES        $130,000

Shareholders Equity:
  Common Stock              $100,000
  Retained Earnings          85,000
  ---------------------------------
  TOTAL EQUITY             $185,000
  ---------------------------------
  TOTAL LIAB. & EQUITY     $315,000
```

> **Verification:** $315,000 = $130,000 + $185,000 (Balanced!)

slides.title: The Income Statement Overview
slides.content:
# The Income Statement

## Also Known As: Profit and Loss Statement (P&L)

The income statement shows a company's **financial performance over a period of time** - revenues, expenses, and resulting profit or loss.

## The Basic Formula

**Revenue - Expenses = Net Income (or Net Loss)**

## Key Components

### Revenue (Top Line)
- Sales of goods or services
- Interest income
- Other operating income

### Cost of Goods Sold (COGS)
- Direct costs of producing goods sold
- Materials, labor, manufacturing overhead

### Gross Profit
**Revenue - COGS = Gross Profit**

### Operating Expenses
- Selling expenses
- General and administrative expenses
- Depreciation and amortization

### Operating Income
**Gross Profit - Operating Expenses = Operating Income**

### Other Items
- Interest expense
- Income tax expense

### Net Income (Bottom Line)
**Operating Income +- Other Items - Taxes = Net Income**

> **Key Terms:** Top Line = Revenue, Bottom Line = Net Income

slides.title: Income Statement Example
slides.content:
# Income Statement in Action

## Sample Income Statement

**ABC Company Income Statement**
*For the Year Ended December 31, 2024*

```
Revenue:
  Net Sales                        $500,000
  Other Revenue                      10,000
  ------------------------------------
  Total Revenue                    $510,000

Cost of Goods Sold                 (200,000)
  ------------------------------------
Gross Profit                       $310,000

Operating Expenses:
  Selling Expenses                  $80,000
  Administrative Expenses            60,000
  Depreciation Expense               20,000
  ------------------------------------
  Total Operating Expenses         (160,000)
  ------------------------------------
Operating Income                   $150,000

Other Income/(Expenses):
  Interest Expense                  (15,000)
  ------------------------------------
Income Before Taxes                $135,000

Income Tax Expense (25%)            (33,750)
  ------------------------------------
Net Income                         $101,250
```

## Key Margins

| Margin | Calculation | Result |
|--------|-------------|--------|
| **Gross Margin** | 310,000 / 510,000 | 60.8% |
| **Operating Margin** | 150,000 / 510,000 | 29.4% |
| **Net Profit Margin** | 101,250 / 510,000 | 19.9% |

> **Analysis:** Higher margins generally indicate better profitability!

slides.title: Single-Step vs Multi-Step Income Statement
slides.content:
# Income Statement Formats

## Single-Step Format

Simple format that groups all revenues and all expenses:

```
Revenues:
  Sales Revenue           $500,000
  Interest Income           5,000
  ----------------------------
  Total Revenues          $505,000

Expenses:
  Cost of Goods Sold      $200,000
  Operating Expenses       150,000
  Interest Expense          15,000
  Income Tax                35,000
  ----------------------------
  Total Expenses          (400,000)
  ----------------------------
Net Income                $105,000
```

## Multi-Step Format

More detailed format showing subtotals:

```
Net Sales                 $500,000
Cost of Goods Sold        (200,000)
  ----------------------------
Gross Profit              $300,000

Operating Expenses        (150,000)
  ----------------------------
Operating Income          $150,000

Other Revenues/Expenses:
  Interest Income            5,000
  Interest Expense         (15,000)
  ----------------------------
Income Before Tax         $140,000

Income Tax Expense         (35,000)
  ----------------------------
Net Income                $105,000
```

## Which to Use?

| Format | Best For |
|--------|----------|
| **Single-Step** | Small businesses, simpler operations |
| **Multi-Step** | Larger companies, detailed analysis |

> **Tip:** Multi-step provides more useful information for analysis!

slides.title: The Cash Flow Statement Overview
slides.content:
# The Cash Flow Statement

## Purpose

The cash flow statement shows **how cash moves in and out** of a business during a period. It explains the change in cash from the beginning to end of the period.

## Why Cash Flow Matters

- **Profitability does not equal cash** - A company can be profitable but cash-poor
- Shows **actual liquidity** position
- Reveals **quality of earnings**
- Essential for **cash planning**

## Three Sections

### 1. Operating Activities
Cash from day-to-day business operations:
- Cash received from customers
- Cash paid to suppliers
- Cash paid for operating expenses
- Interest and taxes paid

### 2. Investing Activities
Cash from buying/selling long-term assets:
- Purchase of equipment
- Sale of investments
- Acquisitions of other companies

### 3. Financing Activities
Cash from funding the business:
- Issuing stock
- Borrowing money
- Repaying loans
- Paying dividends

## The Formula

```
Beginning Cash Balance
+ Cash from Operating Activities
+ Cash from Investing Activities
+ Cash from Financing Activities
= Ending Cash Balance
```

> **Critical:** Ending cash must match the cash on the Balance Sheet!

slides.title: Cash Flow Statement Methods
slides.content:
# Direct vs Indirect Method

## Two Ways to Present Operating Activities

### Direct Method

Shows actual cash receipts and payments:

```
Cash Flows from Operating Activities:

  Cash received from customers    $480,000
  Cash paid to suppliers         (190,000)
  Cash paid for wages             (80,000)
  Cash paid for rent              (24,000)
  Cash paid for interest          (15,000)
  Cash paid for taxes             (30,000)
  ------------------------------------
  Net Cash from Operations        $141,000
```

### Indirect Method

Starts with net income and adjusts for non-cash items:

```
Cash Flows from Operating Activities:

  Net Income                      $101,250
  Adjustments:
    Depreciation Expense           20,000
    Increase in Accounts Rec.     (10,000)
    Decrease in Inventory           8,000
    Increase in Accounts Pay.      12,000
    Decrease in Prepaid Exp.        2,000
  ------------------------------------
  Net Cash from Operations        $133,250
```

## Comparison

| Aspect | Direct | Indirect |
|--------|--------|----------|
| **Shows** | Actual cash flows | Reconciliation |
| **Starting point** | Cash receipts | Net Income |
| **Preferred by** | FASB | Most companies |
| **Ease of prep** | More difficult | Easier |

> **In Practice:** Over 95% of companies use the indirect method!

slides.title: Cash Flow Statement Example
slides.content:
# Complete Cash Flow Statement

**ABC Company Statement of Cash Flows**
*For the Year Ended December 31, 2024*

```
CASH FLOWS FROM OPERATING ACTIVITIES:
  Net Income                           $101,250
  Adjustments for non-cash items:
    Depreciation expense                 20,000
  Changes in working capital:
    Increase in accounts receivable      (5,000)
    Decrease in inventory                 3,000
    Increase in accounts payable          8,000
  ----------------------------------------
  Net Cash from Operating Activities   $127,250

CASH FLOWS FROM INVESTING ACTIVITIES:
  Purchase of equipment               ($45,000)
  Sale of investments                   15,000
  ----------------------------------------
  Net Cash from Investing Activities   ($30,000)

CASH FLOWS FROM FINANCING ACTIVITIES:
  Proceeds from long-term debt         $50,000
  Repayment of short-term debt         (20,000)
  Dividends paid                        (25,000)
  ----------------------------------------
  Net Cash from Financing Activities     $5,000

  ----------------------------------------
NET INCREASE IN CASH                   $102,250
Cash at Beginning of Year                35,000
  ----------------------------------------
CASH AT END OF YEAR                    $137,250
```

## Analysis

- **Positive operating cash flow** - Good sign, core business generates cash
- **Negative investing** - Company is investing in growth
- **Positive financing** - Raised more capital than repaid

slides.title: Statement of Changes in Equity
slides.content:
# Statement of Changes in Equity

## Also Known As: Statement of Retained Earnings (simplified version)

## Purpose

This statement explains **how equity changed** during the period. It bridges the beginning and ending equity balances.

## Components of Equity

### Share Capital
- Common stock
- Preferred stock
- Additional paid-in capital

### Retained Earnings
- Accumulated profits not distributed as dividends
- Increases with net income
- Decreases with net losses and dividends

### Other Comprehensive Income
- Unrealized gains/losses on investments
- Foreign currency translation adjustments
- Pension adjustments

### Treasury Stock
- Company's own shares repurchased
- Reduces total equity

## The Basic Formula

```
Beginning Equity
+ Net Income (or - Net Loss)
+ Other Comprehensive Income
+ Stock Issuances
- Dividends Declared
- Treasury Stock Purchases
= Ending Equity
```

> **Connection:** Ending equity flows directly to the Balance Sheet!

slides.title: Statement of Changes in Equity Example
slides.content:
# Statement of Changes in Equity in Action

**ABC Company Statement of Changes in Equity**
*For the Year Ended December 31, 2024*

```
                      Common   Additional  Retained   Total
                      Stock    Paid-in     Earnings   Equity
                               Capital
----------------------------------------------------------------
Balance, Jan 1       $80,000   $15,000    $58,750   $153,750

Net Income               -         -      101,250    101,250

Dividends Declared       -         -      (25,000)   (25,000)

Stock Issuance        5,000     5,000         -       10,000

----------------------------------------------------------------
Balance, Dec 31      $85,000   $20,000   $135,000   $240,000
```

## What This Tells Us

1. **Net Income** of $101,250 increased retained earnings
2. **Dividends** of $25,000 were distributed to shareholders
3. **New stock** was issued for $10,000
4. **Total equity grew** from $153,750 to $240,000

## Verification

| Change | Amount |
|--------|--------|
| + Net Income | +$101,250 |
| - Dividends | -$25,000 |
| + Stock Issuance | +$10,000 |
| **Net Change** | **+$86,250** |

$153,750 + $86,250 = $240,000 (Correct!)

> **Note:** This ending equity matches the Balance Sheet equity section!

slides.title: How Financial Statements Connect
slides.content:
# The Financial Statement Interconnection

## How They Link Together

### Connection 1: Income Statement to Equity Statement
- **Net Income** flows from Income Statement to Statement of Changes in Equity
- Net Income increases Retained Earnings

### Connection 2: Equity Statement to Balance Sheet
- **Ending Equity** from the equity statement becomes the equity section of the Balance Sheet

### Connection 3: Balance Sheet to Cash Flow Statement
- **Beginning and ending cash** must match the cash flow statement
- Changes in balance sheet accounts explain cash flows

### Connection 4: Cash Flow to Balance Sheet
- **Ending cash** from the cash flow statement matches cash on the Balance Sheet

## Visual Flow

```
  INCOME STATEMENT
         |
         | Net Income
         v
  STATEMENT OF CHANGES IN EQUITY
         |
         | Ending Equity
         v
  BALANCE SHEET  <----  CASH FLOW STATEMENT
     (Cash)               (Ending Cash)
```

## Practical Verification

When reviewing financial statements:
1. Check Net Income ties from IS to Equity Statement
2. Check Ending Equity ties to Balance Sheet
3. Check Ending Cash ties from Cash Flow to Balance Sheet

> **Integrity Check:** If the statements do not tie, there is an error somewhere!

slides.title: Reading Financial Statements
slides.content:
# How to Analyze Financial Statements

## Step-by-Step Approach

### Step 1: Start with the Income Statement
- Is the company profitable?
- Are revenues growing?
- Are margins healthy?

### Step 2: Review the Balance Sheet
- What assets does the company own?
- How much debt does it carry?
- Is equity growing?

### Step 3: Analyze Cash Flows
- Is operating cash flow positive?
- Is the company investing in growth?
- How is it financing operations?

### Step 4: Check the Equity Statement
- Are retained earnings growing?
- Were dividends paid?
- Was new stock issued?

## Key Questions to Ask

| Statement | Key Questions |
|-----------|---------------|
| **Income** | Is it profitable? Growing? |
| **Balance** | Can it pay its debts? |
| **Cash Flow** | Does it generate cash? |
| **Equity** | Is owner value increasing? |

## Red Flags to Watch

- Net income positive but operating cash flow negative
- Growing debt faster than equity
- Declining margins over time
- Large unexplained changes in accounts

> **Tip:** Always read all four statements together for the complete picture!

slides.title: Financial Statement Users
slides.content:
# Who Uses Financial Statements?

## Internal Users

### Management
- Make strategic decisions
- Plan budgets and forecasts
- Evaluate performance
- Identify problems early

### Employees
- Assess job security
- Negotiate compensation
- Understand company health

## External Users

### Investors and Shareholders
- Decide to buy, hold, or sell stock
- Evaluate management performance
- Assess dividend potential

### Creditors and Lenders
- Evaluate creditworthiness
- Set loan terms and conditions
- Monitor existing loans

### Government and Regulators
- Calculate taxes owed
- Ensure compliance
- Monitor industry health

### Analysts and Advisors
- Make recommendations
- Value companies
- Identify trends

## Information Needs

| User | Primary Interest |
|------|------------------|
| Investors | Profitability, growth potential |
| Creditors | Liquidity, solvency |
| Management | All aspects |
| Government | Tax liability |
| Employees | Stability, profitability |

> **Remember:** Financial statements are designed to meet the needs of diverse users!

slides.title: Notes to Financial Statements
slides.content:
# Notes to Financial Statements

## What Are Notes?

Notes (or footnotes) provide **additional detail and explanations** that cannot fit in the main financial statements.

## Why Notes Matter

- Explain accounting policies used
- Provide detail behind summary numbers
- Disclose contingencies and commitments
- Required by GAAP and IFRS

## Common Note Disclosures

### Accounting Policies
- Revenue recognition method
- Depreciation method
- Inventory valuation method

### Detail on Specific Accounts
- Breakdown of property and equipment
- Aging of accounts receivable
- Long-term debt terms and maturity

### Contingencies
- Pending lawsuits
- Environmental liabilities
- Guarantees

### Related Party Transactions
- Transactions with owners
- Transactions with affiliates

### Subsequent Events
- Significant events after balance sheet date
- Acquisitions, disasters, major contracts

## Example Note

```
Note 5: Inventory

Inventory is valued at the lower of cost or
net realizable value using the FIFO method.

                        2024        2023
Raw Materials        $15,000     $12,000
Work in Progress      10,000       8,000
Finished Goods        20,000      18,000
-------------------------
Total Inventory      $45,000     $38,000
```

> **Tip:** Always read the notes - they contain crucial information!

slides.title: Common Financial Statement Errors
slides.content:
# Avoiding Common Mistakes

## Preparation Errors

### Classification Errors
- Putting current items in non-current section
- Mixing operating and non-operating items
- Misclassifying cash flow activities

### Timing Errors
- Recording revenue in wrong period
- Missing accruals at period end
- Incorrect depreciation calculations

### Mathematical Errors
- Calculation mistakes
- Incorrect totals and subtotals
- Balance sheet does not balance

## Interpretation Errors

### Ignoring Context
- Not comparing to prior periods
- Not considering industry norms
- Overlooking notes and disclosures

### Over-Reliance on One Statement
- Looking only at income (ignoring cash)
- Looking only at profits (ignoring debt)

### Misunderstanding Metrics
- Confusing cash and accrual figures
- Misinterpreting ratios

## Prevention Checklist

- [ ] Balance sheet balances
- [ ] Net income ties to equity statement
- [ ] Cash ties between statements
- [ ] All accounts properly classified
- [ ] Comparative periods included
- [ ] Notes are complete

> **Best Practice:** Always have someone else review your financial statements!

slides.title: Summary and Key Takeaways
slides.content:
# Congratulations! Summary

You have completed the **Financial Statements** lesson! Here is what you learned:

## The Four Financial Statements

### Balance Sheet
- Shows financial position at a point in time
- **Assets = Liabilities + Equity**
- Current and non-current classifications

### Income Statement
- Shows performance over a period
- **Revenue - Expenses = Net Income**
- Gross profit, operating income, net income

### Cash Flow Statement
- Shows cash movements over a period
- Three sections: Operating, Investing, Financing
- Direct vs indirect methods

### Statement of Changes in Equity
- Explains changes in equity over a period
- Connects net income to balance sheet equity

## Key Connections

| From | To | What Flows |
|------|-----|------------|
| Income Statement | Equity Statement | Net Income |
| Equity Statement | Balance Sheet | Ending Equity |
| Cash Flow | Balance Sheet | Ending Cash |

## What is Next?

Now you are ready to explore:
- Accounting concepts and terminology
- Journal entries and ledgers
- Financial ratio analysis

> **Remember:** Financial statements tell the story of a business - learn to read that story well!
